title: Thursday, 29th November 2018
bodyHTML:
11:08 am

Thursday, then. Hello. Good morning. Hi. Welcome.

Tom Dalgleish The thing where we are trained in the inner workings of newspapers

And we're up. 43 point on the FTSE live because of mildly dovish Fed messaging.

Pharma The thing where Bryce contributes to the death of his day job.
Soundbuy Hello
FJ Deutsche Virgin Islands
chad_john The thing where we all have our trading accounts ready for any tasty RAWsels

As in, Powell saying that the current US interest rates were "just below" the neutral range and that there was no "preset policy path".

Okay, so I'm not a Fed watcher. That's a branch of journalism that transcends explanation ......

............. And to me, a non Fed watcher, the comments seem innocuous. Bland even.

But apparently we have to see them as a counterpoint to the "we're a long way from neutral" stuff a couple of months ago.

nightingale20201 morning
Rick Chasey BE - still a step ahead of oil price watchers in Vienna...
red fed will raise in dec. powells comments relate to what happens nxt year. underlining that they acknowledge risks and are watching data. essentially that neutral is very close.
BE11:14am

But why would you care what I think when you could not care what Goldman thinks:

BE11:14am

In his remarks yesterday, Fed Chairman Powell mentioned that the policy rate was “just below the broad range” of estimates of the neutral rate, highlighting both the significant uncertainty around neutral rate estimates and the fact that current rates remain below the lowest of the Fed’s model estimates of neutral. He reiterated a gradual path—interpreted in our view to mean quarterly rate hikes—as the middle ground between the risks of hiking too quickly and too slowly. We leave our subjective odds of a December hike unchanged at 90%.

Shinshin I guess this year's DB bonuses will contain more shares than ever
nightingale20201 more media is probably on Carney (BOE) doom day scenario
11:15 am
BE11:15am

Or Panmure, which is less pretty much equivalent to Goldman. More or less.

red carneys boe well known to support remain, or failing that, as close ties as poss. they are allowed a technical view but shudnt be political
BE11:15am

This affirms our view that the divergence of Developed World monetary policy will act as a break on the US tightening cycle – something brought forward by the looming deflationary impact of oil and a strengthening US Dollar. These cyclical factors add to our long-held view that the spread of digitally-enabled price transparency has structurally lowered pricing power and core inflationary pressures. We continue to see two US rate increases in 2019, leading to US rates at a neutral stance at our estimated r* of 3%; a nominal level just half the level seen during past cycles.

Pi1010 What Goldman thinks and what Goldman says is the exact opposite ..usually.
BE11:16am

Congratulations to Merrill, by the way, for the headline: "Situation Room: Throwing in the Powell"

Excel Developer Santa Rally grey?
11:17 am
BE11:17am

They note corporate bonds barely budged "as investors are drinking from the supply fire hose."

BE11:18am

Also, Nomura.

BE11:18am

When interest rates were well-below plausible estimates of the neutral rate, the direction of policy tightening was relatively clear. As the Committee approaches the range of neutral rate estimates, it makes sense for a more cautious, “wait and see” approach. In that sense, Powell’s comments suggest that the Committee will soon be making monetary policy choices in response to the incoming data. That is consistent with Powell’s emphasis in Dallas of increased flexibility, including holding post-meeting press conferences after every meeting in 2019.
Powell did sound a note of optimism today, saying that “there is a great deal to like” about the current economic outlook. However, he also said that the Committee “will be paying very close attention to what incoming economic and financial data are telling us.”

11:18 am
BE11:18am

With inflation essentially at the Committee’s 2% target and further declines in the unemployment rate, we continue to expect a rate hike in December. The main focus of the meeting will be any changes to the Committee’s forecasts for 2019. At the moment, participants’ forecasts for 2019 suggest a roughly even split between two, three and four rate hikes, but the median “dot” implies three total rate hikes, one more than our forecast. Powell’s remarks today, and comments from other participants over the intermeeting period, suggest that both growth and policy rate forecasts for 2019 could be lowered at the December meeting. As our growth and policy rate forecasts are currently below the Committee’s, the downward revisions in SEP would be consistent with our outlook.

BE11:19am

All of which leads me to ponder why on earth we're up. But then, as I emphasise, I'm not a Fed watcher.

BE11:24am

The uniform consensus amongst conventional economists is that trade barriers are poor for economic growth. So it should be no surprise that yesterday’s assessment by the Bank of England indicated that under all scenarios Brexit will hurt the UK economy — the only question being how much. The Bank set out that a ‘no-deal’ outcome could reduce UK GDP by 7-10% versus the previous trends over a ten-year period. In the worst case outcome, the unemployment rate might rise to 7.5%, house prices fall by 30%, commercial property prices by 48% and sterling depreciates by a further 25%. However, even adopting Theresa May’s deal entails costs for the UK economy, which would be smaller over the longer term, by -1% to -3%.

BE11:24am

A surprise for some investors was that Bank clearly spelled out it would raise rates in a ‘no-deal’ outcome. In a disorderly ‘no-deal’ Brexit, the simulations implied rates could rise to 4% to combat a surge in CPI inflation to 6%, pushed up by tariffs and a sharp depreciation of sterling. Of course, if Theresa May’s deal eventually passes through Parliament, the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) will probably raise rates in early 2019. The November Inflation Report projections were for CPI inflation to exceed 2% over a two-year time horizon, a sure fire signal that the MPC would raise rates were it not for the uncertainty of Brexit.

Lemmy worth reminding on the BoE's own words "Our analysis includes scenarios not forecasts"
red @Pi1010as long as they get the logistics side sorted out so goods/servs can move, there will be a relief bounce evn on a no deal plus scenario. tariffs are no prob for comps, its actually the phyiscal movement side of things. they need protocol on this sorted

IslandDweller @Pi1010 If your business is dependent on free movement of goods and services into EU, how do you plan for a no deal? It stops your business in its tracks
Excel Developer @IslandDweller: deploy more capital per UK worker perhaps?

So anyway, you can either believe the BOE's predictions or dismiss them. Up to you. That's the nature of predictions. The only real takeaway for investors is that, under the BOE's no-deal scenario, banks are fine.

Pharma Have to laugh about the tariff line. Why is the default assumption that the UK would impose EU-external tariffs on all trade? Why not zero? Or as a default, set the average tariff to a rate that was revenue neutral (~1/10th of average EU rate, given EU/nonEU split, and the80% of tariffs currently paid to Brussels)
IslandDweller @red. The chief exec of Dover has said they can't cope if EU goods have to go through same checks as non-EU. It grinds to a halt

If you're arguing that the BOE's being over-pessimistic for political reasons then you're also arguing that banks must be absolutely bomb-proof and I assume you're filling your boots.

BE11:29am

Berenberg incoming.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

The headline message, that all UK banks passed the Bank of England’s (BOE) 2018 stress test, obscures important sources of differentiation, in our view. As the only listed UK banks to remain above all requirements at all times, we believe RBS and Standard Chartered emerge as clear winners. This further underpins our view that both banks trade at too wide a discount to their nearest peers (Lloyds and HSBC). While more nuanced, the results also provide comfort that Barclays holds sufficient capital. This has been the key non-Brexit related concern among investors following our upgrade of Barclays earlier this year.

red @IslandDwellerthey have had 2 years to work on it, thats a failing of the government. work needs to take place to correct this.
red @Pharmaif completely no deal, which is almost impossible, must be on wto terms as cannot favour anyone over anyone else
BE11:30am

"risks priced into UK banks have decoupled from broader measures of risk" has been Berenberg's argument for some time.

wayneJ RPC - is this move driven by INTU deal break?
IslandDweller Two years in which NOTHING has been done. So no deal means Dover would grind to a halt. This "someone will sort it out" delusion is dangerous
Pharma @IslandDweller. But WHY would they have to go through the same checks? Regulations are identical now, and will be after the 30th March. There is no need for addiotnal checks, at least until such time regulations significantly diverge, which will be months/years.All this "we'll have to check everything" is the government trying to scare everyone witless.
tadam So will RPC follow Intu? Intu was trading at a crazy discount to the offer price. (like no discount).
BE11:31am

Interpretation of this year’s stress test results is complicated further by the use of IFRS 9 for the first time. We, nevertheless, draw three conclusions. First, the fact that cumulative UK loan loss rates over the fiveyear scenario are, in aggregate, similar to those in the BOE’s 2017 test provides some reassurance about underlying asset quality trends. Second, the BOE’s observation that IFRS 9 had the greatest adverse impact on banks with the most consumer lending reinforces our recommendation to avoid the most cyclically exposed banks. Third, the fact that Standard Chartered’s overall stressed capital impact fell yoy, despite IFRS 9, demonstrates the bank’s de-risking (contrary to investor perception).

11:31 am
BE11:32am

Widespread excess capital does not exist: The BOE’s stress tests remain the binding constraint on UK banks’ capital, in our view. With the BOE having stabilised its approach to designing stress test scenarios and “pass marks” (in particular UK bank’s systemic buffers) there are now fewer ways in which capital requirements may rise. Such risks have not, however, disappeared. First, we do not regard the BOE’s transitional treatment of IFRS 9 as future-proof. This may pose a headwind to Barclays and Lloyds in particular. Second, we are mindful that the introduction of ring-fencing, from 2019, may lead to greater overall requirements.

The withdrawal of the offer has some stark implications for the company
and sector in our view. With two potential takeover deals failing in the last
year, one from the listed space and one from the direct space, it begs the
question of who the potential suitor for this business could now be? With
the LTV now through 50%, this capital constrained business has committed
to more capital recycling, although clearly in this market it will be difficult to execute without significant discounts in our view. As such it is little surprise in our view that the dividend has been cut to maintain the cash within the business to try and manage the capital structure.

red @IslandDwellermini deals from jan to march next year. i cannot see any chance of no deal fullstop. there is not a single person that is in favour of absolutely nothing. no deal for eg means as you say no food transfer, flights etc. hence it can only be no deal plus, lots of mini arrangements.

While no specific reason has been given for the consortium’s decision, other than heightened macro-economic uncertainty, it was noted in last week’s offer extension announcement that it had “made substantial progress on the financing of the possible offer” and that the “indicative proposal remains subject to certain pre-conditions, including the Consortium completing its financing arrangements with its lender group” and we wonder whether this could have been a problem.

UK retail margins are rapidly declining in the face of weak sales growth, online cannibalisation and cost inflation. As retailers are happy to point out, this is not sustainable. Restoring retailer margins to 2015 levels would require a c.40% cut to occupancy costs (rents and business rates). Rental value declines for UK retail look set to accelerate in 2019e.

UK logistics has re-priced dramatically but we would argue this is justified based on superior total return prospects, underpinned by healthy rental growth.

Interim adjusted operating profit of £214 million was up 6% on an
underlying basis, normalising for adverse FX and polymer price
movements, and 1% lower than our forecast. Organic growth was 3.2%
and normalised operating margins were flat y/y. We were encouraged to
see FCF come in above expectations and adjusting items (apart from the
amortisation of acquisition intangibles) dwindling to almost nothing. We
have updated our numbers, but there is no material change to headline
estimates. We remain OW, although lower peer company multiples in our
SOTP valuation bring our target price down to 1,000p, Dec-19.

wayneJ @Lemmy - interesting - of course risk of an extension

irish hedge fund guy INTU purpose is to "put a smile on the face of our customers. We want them to be happier after a visit to our centres than when they walked through the door. We know that happy customers mean happy retailers" Not a very scientific purpose. Mind you at £1.25 it must be a bargain at this level!
BE11:52am

Interims included adj. EBIT of £214.6m (+3%, +3% CCY) and adj. EPS of 35.4p (+1%, +2% CCY), due to the lag in passing on higher polymer costs, while organic growth improved to 3.2%. Assuming a similar headwind in H2 and updating for company guidance, we trim our 2019 adj. EPS estimate by c.2%. We lower our target price to 960p, from 1,130p, to reflect a more appropriate valuation aspiration, based on current peer group valuation ratings. The shares remain inexpensive, based on our revised estimates, trading on Mar-19 EV/EBITDA and P/E multiples of 7.1x and 10.2x, with a potential near-term catalyst.

Lemmy wayneJ: yes, but they've had one already
